stem: A 22-year-old trauma client has been in a deep coma with fixed/dilated pupils for 48 hours following a severe TBI. Based on the documentation in the Critical Neuro & Brain Death Protocol Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Initiation of brain death determination protocol.
Background: MV accident with severe diffuse axonal injury.
Assessment: Client is GCS 3T. No spontaneous respirations.
Recommendation: Formal apnea test and OPO notification.

tabs.title: Brain Death Protocol Log
tabs.content:
CriteriaCurrent FindingInterpretation
Pupillary Light ReflexAbsent (Fixed/Dilated)Brainstem failure
Corneal / Gag ReflexesAbsentBrainstem failure
Apnea TestPCO2 reached 62 mmHg; No effortPositive for Brain Death
Doll’s Eyes (Oculocephalic)No eye movementBrainstem failure

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 90/52 (Pressor dependent), HR 68, RR 0 (Vent dependent), T 95.2°F (Poikilothermia).

actionOptions.text: Notify the local Organ Procurement Organization (OPO) as required by law
Maintain hemodynamic stability (Fluids/Pressors) to preserve organ function
Instruct the family that the 'machine' is keeping the client alive
Initiate aggressive range-of-motion as recovery is likely

parameterOptions.text: Absence of brainstem reflexes and spontaneous respiration
Verification of a normothermic core temperature (> 36°C) for valid testing
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is Clinical Brain Death (c2). The criteria for brain death require a known cause (TBI), absence of brainstem reflexes (p1), and a positive apnea test (CO2 > 60 with no effort). Crucially, the nurse must ensure the client is NORMOTHERMIC (p2) before testing, as hypothermia can mimic brain death. Once declared, the nurse MUST notify the OPO (a1) and maintain donor stability (a2) to ensure organ viability if donation proceeds.
clinicalPearls: Poikilothermia (taking on the room temperature) is common in brain death as the hypothalamus fails.
The nurse should NOT initiate the conversation about organ donation; that is the job of the OPO representative.
Fixed and dilated pupils in brain death are usually mid-position (4-6mm), not always fully 'blown.'

questionTrap.trap: Asking the family about organ donation before the OPO arrives.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Legally, only trained OPO staff should make the 'request' to avoid conflicts of interest and ensure high-quality communication.

mnemonic.title: Brain Gone
mnemonic.expansion: G-Gag absent. O-Ocular (Doll's eyes) absent. N-No Breathing (Apnea test). E-EEG flat/Brainstem dead.
